text: Hello, everyone! Looking for some advice/opinions, how well can I expect a company’s blog to work for cross/upsell? SaaS B2B context. I’m personally a bit skeptical most of existing customers will be very interested in reading the blog since they’ve already found and invested in the solution they were looking for.

elements.text: Hello, everyone! Looking for some advice/opinions, how well can I expect a company’s blog to work for cross/upsell? SaaS B2B context. I’m personally a bit skeptical most of existing customers will be very interested in reading the blog since they’ve already found and invested in the solution they were looking for.

text: I think it’s all about helping them get the most out of the solution! If you can help them get their money’s worth, they’ll read it. Make your blog feel like a service, not a sales tool

elements.text: I think it’s all about helping them get the most out of the solution! If you can help them get their money’s worth, they’ll read it. Make your blog feel like a service, not a sales tool

text: I think it depends on your content distribution. If you can get those blog pieces in your base newsletters / in-app and on upsell/integration drips, they can help tremendously. Upsell / cross-sell is just another funnel, so blog content can be excellent for that courtship.

elements.text: I think it depends on your content distribution. If you can get those blog pieces in your base newsletters / in-app and on upsell/integration drips, they can help tremendously. Upsell / cross-sell is just another funnel, so blog content can be excellent for that courtship.

text:
Your CS team should always be looking for touch points to be helpful to customers before the renewal. Content can be a great way to do that.

I would interview someone in the CS role and learn about how they are doing it today. I'm guessing there is an opportunity for you to plug in and make the experience better.

text:
Does anyone have a basic "Hacker News" strategy for early stage startups? I would like to get my CEO more active in the community. He's been developing some useful frameworks for developers building out data systems and I view HN as a way to share his learnings.

Does anyone have a high level 'just the basics' of what a Hacker News strategy may look like?

elements.text:
Does anyone have a basic "Hacker News" strategy for early stage startups? I would like to get my CEO more active in the community. He's been developing some useful frameworks for developers building out data systems and I view HN as a way to share his learnings.

Does anyone have a high level 'just the basics' of what a Hacker News strategy may look like?

text: Nice to meet you too! Feel free to connect on LinkedIn as well and happy to help connect you.

elements.text: Nice to meet you too! Feel free to connect on LinkedIn as well and happy to help connect you.

text:
I've written a bunch of posts over the years that hit the front page there, and maybe 4-5 that hit the number one spot.  From that applied experience, here's my take:
• It's an unreliable medium for views -- most of the stuff you submit will go nowhere fast, and there really is no magic formula (else the same entities would be up there a lot)
• If you're going to submit your own stuff, have an account where you submit a lot of stuff besides your own to avoid looking transparently self-promotional.
• If you can get others to put your content there, that's much better.
• Tease controversial, "make enemies" Moz style positions out of the CEO.   If your company makes, say, an automated testing tool, "It's Unprofessional Not to Test in 2021" will be much more likely to trend there than "Reasons You Should Test."  Every post I ever had there that drove 10K+ views from the medium had a title like "The Beggar CEO and Sucker Culture" or "Hiring is Broken and It Isn't Worth Fixing."
• If you're going the non-rant style, original insights or unprecedented things do well, like "I just rewrote the original Mario Brothers as a browser app"
• If it were me, I'd have a primary purpose/plan for the content that wasn't trending on Hacker News.  IOW, you have a plan for the content and treat trending on HN as a bonus, should it happen.
• Don't let your CEO read the comments.  :wink:

elements.text: I've written a bunch of posts over the years that hit the front page there, and maybe 4-5 that hit the number one spot.  From that applied experience, here's my take:
It's an unreliable medium for views -- most of the stuff you submit will go nowhere fast, and there really is no magic formula (else the same entities would be up there a lot)
If you're going to submit your own stuff, have an account where you submit a lot of stuff besides your own to avoid looking transparently self-promotional.
If you can get others to put your content there, that's much better.

Tease controversial, "make enemies" Moz style positions out of the CEO.   If your company makes, say, an automated testing tool, "It's Unprofessional Not to Test in 2021" will be much more likely to trend there than "Reasons You Should Test."  Every post I ever had there that drove 10K+ views from the medium had a title like "The Beggar CEO and Sucker Culture" or "Hiring is Broken and It Isn't Worth Fixing."
If you're going the non-rant style, original insights or unprecedented things do well, like "I just rewrote the original Mario Brothers as a browser app"
If it were me, I'd have a primary purpose/plan for the content that wasn't trending on Hacker News.  IOW, you have a plan for the content and treat trending on HN as a bonus, should it happen.
Don't let your CEO read the comments.

text: Anyway, other people's mileage may vary, but I've picked up a few hundred k visitors from the platform over the years, so I feel like I can at least somewhat speak from experience.

elements.text: Anyway, other people's mileage may vary, but I've picked up a few hundred k visitors from the platform over the years, so I feel like I can at least somewhat speak from experience.

text:
Agree with most of <@U017XD7H4P7>’s points. HN is hard. The audience is happy to tear you apart if they get a whiff of salesy-ness, and most of your contributions will not make it to the front page. But the payoff is great when it happens! A few other points:

• Make sure you’re following all the rules. I wouldn’t try astroturfing; their algorithms are really skilled at detecting it  and automatically banning / shadowbanning offenders.
• I actually think it’s good for the CEO to engage in the comments, but only if he knows his stuff and can handle criticism. And can spend all day responding to comments in case a post DOES make it to the front page :grin:
• If you really think HN is a good channel for you, see if you can recruit others to be active, build karma, and do brand advocacy there (in an organic and non-spammy way). A few accounts with good track records will come in handy for future submissions.

elements.text: Agree with most of

’s points. HN is hard. The audience is happy to tear you apart if they get a whiff of salesy-ness, and most of your contributions will not make it to the front page. But the payoff is great when it happens! A few other points:
Make sure you’re following all the rules. I wouldn’t try astroturfing; their algorithms are really skilled at detecting it  and automatically banning / shadowbanning offenders.

I actually think it’s good for the CEO to engage in the comments, but only if he knows his stuff and can handle criticism. And can spend all day responding to comments in case a post DOES make it to the front page

If you really think HN is a good channel for you, see if you can recruit others to be active, build karma, and do brand advocacy there (in an organic and non-spammy way). A few accounts with good track records will come in handy for future submissions.

text: If one is evaluating a social presence for a healthcare/pharma brand, any cool tools to use? Know a lot of the general market ones but in a specialized category wonder if there's something more specific to use or a different way to attack it. Most of the priority audiences would be providers, patients, employees/recruiting, and investors. maybe media/influencers too.

text:
<@U01LLSRQ57A> Depending on your exact area, I might consider whether there’s an HN for your niche that your CEO could build an expertise profile in? Or not even necessarily a site, but maybe it’s a private Slack, or a subreddit, or something like that where you can invest a small amount of time to become “known”.

I would say that in my experience, it still takes a long time – it’s a consistency game. Way better to be helpful in the community a couple times a week for a year, than to try doing it intensely for a short amount of time.

Thanks <@U013WCZ5GSV> - I appreciate the sentiment. I am looking at opportunities to discuss what data-driven means from a technical / developer standpoint.

I've been on HN for a few years and see their audience as caring about this topic (how do you use data analytics to inform your product choices/business decisions) but the points Eliza and Erik bring up are giving me some pause.
